titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: The Rosenbachs were a prominent Jewish Philadelphia family. Morris (born Meier) Rosenbach emigrated from Germany to the United States in 1844, and became a US citizen in 1855. In 1857 he married Isabella H. Polock. They had eight children: Hyman Polock (1858-1892), Philip Hyman (1863-1953), Morris (1865-?), Rebecca H. (1866-1926), Adalaide (1868-1872), Moses Polock (1870-1953), Miriam H. Wolfe (1873-1926), and Abraham Simon Wolf (1876-1952). Morris Rosenbach, Sr. was a soft goods merchant. His wife Isabella was involved with the Hebrew Sunday School Society, the Hebrew Female Benevolent Society, the Jewish Orphans Home, and Congregation Mikveh Israel. Moses Polock (1817-1903) was the brother of Isabella Polock Rosenbach. As a young man, he was employed by the publishing and bookselling firm of M'Carty & Davis as a clerk. Twenty years later Polock acquired the business and upon his death, the firm descended to Abraham Rosenbach. Hyman was a freelance journalist and later worked as a regular staff member at the Public Ledger. Morris Jr. was an engineer who worked for a time for the Missouri River Commission. He eventually settled in Chicago and was an executive for the packing house of Wilson and Company. Abraham received his Ph.D. from the University of Pennsylvania in 1898. In 1903, he and his older brother Philip established the Rosenbach Company to sell rare books and fine and decorative arts.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the Rosenbach family papers. Materials in the collection include: correspondence between family members, including a series of letters from Morris (Jr.) to his mother, sisters, and Abraham describing his travels in the western United States in the late 1890s; the passport, naturalization papers, and military service records of Morris Rosenbach (in German); business books related to Morris Rosenbach's business; school notebooks and a penmanship book of Isabella Rosenbach; a scrapbook, minutes, and histories of the Hebrew Sunday School Society; school notebooks, composition books, notes, and school papers of Abraham; honorary degrees and awards belonging to Abraham; clippings, printed profiles, and a typescript of a speech by Edwin Wolf related to Abraham; bibliographic cards for works on and by Tennyson (probably compiled by Abraham); address and phone books of Philip and Abraham; business books related to Philip's Carlton Club; estate papers of Philip and Abraham; blueprints for the building at 1618 Locust street; printed copies and a manuscript of Hyman Polock Rosenbach's Jews in Philadelphia Prior to 1800; commonplace books; calling cards of family members; and a typescript of the memoirs of Cyrus Adler.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
